title: How the Bidens Treat Hunter’s Daughter
description: Readers discuss a column by Maureen Dowd critical of the president. Also: Serving gay people; faith communities; Indiana Jones; Ron DeSantis and Goofy.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Johannesburg Sees First Snowfall in Over a Decade. Residents Flock to the Flakes.
description: A light dusting of snow coated many parts of Johannesburg on Monday, driving children and adults to nearby parks and playgrounds.
content: Snow fell in Johannesburg this week for the first time in more than a decade, causing a flurry of activity among residents eager to see the rare winter wonderland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: The Energy Transition Is Underway. Fossil Fuel Workers Could Be Left Behind.
description: The Biden administration is trying to increase renewable energy investments in distressed regions, but some are skeptical those measures would be enough to make up for job losses.
content: Tiffany Berger spent more than a decade working at a coal-fired power plant in Coshocton County, Ohio, eventually becoming a unit operator making about $100,000 annually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey L. Fisher
title: The Supreme Court’s Conservatives Control Even More Than You Realize
description: In addition to deciding cases, those justices also have the votes to decide which cases the court hears, setting the agenda in the process.
content: Add this to the ways in which the Supreme Court is increasingly resembling just another political institution: Only one side of the ideological divide has the power to set the institution’s agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tenzin Tsagong
title: An Exiled Publisher Creates a ‘Brotherhood Across Tibetans’
description: Buchung Sonam co-founded a press to nurture the writing of Tibetans, helping provide through literature a sense of home for a stateless population.
content: In the winter of 1982, Bhuchung Sonam left his home in Central Tibet. For five days, he trekked with his father across the Himalayas to the Nepali border. Only around 11 years old then, he knew little about what they were fleeing — China’s decades-long colonization of his homeland — and why. He also didn’t realize that he would never again see his homeland, his mother or his six siblings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
title: Erdogan Says Yes, but Not So Fast, to Sweden’s NATO Bid
description: After voicing his support for Sweden joining NATO, President Erdogan of Turkey said Sweden needed to take more steps to win the support of his country’s parliament, which he said will not take up the matter until October.
content: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on Wednesday tempered the expectation that his expression of support this week for Sweden joining NATO meant that he would swiftly push the approval through the Turkish parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Far From the Tour de France, Colombia Falls Hard for Cycling
description: Soccer still reigns supreme in Latin America, but a popular ride in the hills above Medellín showcases a nation’s second love.
content: The route up Las Palmas starts near the valley floor, but it doesn’t stay there for long. It is 10 miles up to the summit, an arduous climb of roughly 3,400 vertical feet, a journey of long rises and sharp turns, of straining muscles and heaving lungs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Gerald C. Meyers, C.E.O. Who Paved Way for the S.U.V., Dies at 94
description: He led a struggling but innovative (if not quirky) American Motors to record profits and helped fuel an appetite for off-road vehicles with the Jeep Cherokee.
content: Gerald C. Meyers, a former chief executive of the American Motors Corporation who helped spark the nation’s obsession with sport utility vehicles and oversaw the development of some of the quirkiest cars of the 1970s, died on June 19 at his home in West Bloomfield, Mich. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: versatile
description: This word has appeared in 199 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word versatile has appeared in 199 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 27 in the Opinion essay “The Newest Immigrants Will Change American Spanish. That’s a Good Thing” by Ilan Stavans:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Fischer
title: Polls Were Great in 2022. Can They Repeat Their Success in 2024?
description: Experiments that yielded promising results in 2022 may not be enough if Trump is on the ballot again.
content: With a highly successful polling cycle behind them, some pollsters believe a tactic that gained widespread adoption in 2022 may help carry them through the next presidential election. But even the tactic’s adherents say it may not be a panacea, particularly if former President Donald J. Trump is once again on the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Hits Trump for Skipping Iowa Event and Refusing to Commit to Debate
description: “Nobody is entitled to this nomination,” Ron DeSantis told a conservative radio host. “I’ll be at all the debates because the American people deserve to hear from us directly.”
content: In a radio interview on Wednesday, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida chastised former President Donald J. Trump for planning to skip a gathering of presidential candidates in Iowa this weekend, as well as for not committing to a Republican Party debate next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Levkowitz
title: Scapegoated by Everyone, Wanted by No One
description: Syrians in Turkey do not want to go home. They may not have a choice.
content: ANTAKYA, Turkey — It was the Syrians who were responsible for the earthquakes. That’s what a Turkish man told Seyfeddin Selim, a refugee from Homs, Syria, who used to sell groceries in Antakya, the capital of Hatay province in southern Turkey. When the earthquakes hit in February, Mr. Selim’s shop was cleared out by looters before he could get there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Judge Allows Re-enactment of Parkland School Shooting for Civil Case
description: The families of several victims sought the re-enactment as part of their lawsuit against a former deputy who was at the scene of the 2018 shooting but did not confront the gunman.
content: Sometime in the next few weeks, someone carrying an assault-style rifle — loaded with blank rounds instead of live ammunition — will re-enact how a gunman carried out a deadly mass shooting five years ago at a Florida high school. A judge decided on Wednesday to allow the re-enactment as part of a civil suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: On TV Killer Fungi Are a Horror Plotline. In This Book They’re Real.
description: “Blight,” by Emily Monosson, chronicles the threats fungal pathogens pose to humans, animals and plants as the world’s most devastating agents of disease.
content: There’s a scene in Don DeLillo’s novel “White Noise” in which the protagonist reminisces with an ex-wife who was “ultrasensitive to many things,” as she puts it. “Sunlight, air, food, water, sex,” he says. She doesn’t disagree: “Carcinogenic, every one of them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Emmy Snubs and Surprises: ‘Jury Duty’ In, ‘Yellowstone’ Still Out
description: The 75th Primetime Emmy nominations proceeded mostly as anticipated on Wednesday, but there were a few surprises.
content: With minor exceptions, the major categories were filled in the expected ways when the 2023 Primetime Emmys nominations were announced on Wednesday. Some surprises cropped up further down the page, where the members of the Television Academy apparently started checking off every name they saw from favored shows like “Ted Lasso” and “The White Lotus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: F.T.C.’s Court Loss Raises Fresh Questions About Its Chair’s Strategy
description: Lina Khan has said a fear of defeat should not deter the agency from suing big tech companies. But after Microsoft won a ruling this week, her critics say that strategy is flawed.
content: Lina Khan became chair of the Federal Trade Commission two years ago on a promise to bring bold action against the biggest tech companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: To Help Cool a Hot Planet, the Whitest of White Coats
description: Scientists at Purdue have created a white paint that, when applied, can reduce the surface temperature on a roof and cool the building beneath it.
content: Xiulin Ruan, a professor of mechanical engineering at Purdue University, didn’t set out to make it into the Guinness World Records when he began trying to make a new type of paint. He had a loftier goal: to cool down buildings without torching the Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What the Microsoft-Activision Ruling Means for the Future of Deal-Making
description: Corporate leaders are feeling emboldened by another legal defeat for the Federal Trade Commission, though the agency may still fight to block the takeover.
content: A federal judge’s decision to let Microsoft close its $70 billion takeover of the video game maker Activision Blizzard didn’t just represent a win for the tech giant. It’s also a major blow to the F.T.C., which had sought to block the transaction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: She Steals Surfboards by the Seashore. She’s a Sea Otter.
description: California wildlife officials are hoping to apprehend a 5-year-old sea otter, who has a knack for riding the waves after committing longboard larceny.
content: For the past few summers, numerous surfers in Santa Cruz, Calif., have been victims of a crime at sea: boardjacking. The culprit is a female sea otter, who accosts the wave riders, seizing and even damaging their surfboards in the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: Who Is Daddy’s Little Meatball?
description: The slogan has taken over New York City’s souvenir shops, and the T-shirts are worn by tourists and downtown Manhattanites alike.
content: On an afternoon in June, Erica Scalise was walking through Little Italy in Manhattan when the window of a kitschy souvenir shop gave her pause. Hanging in the display was a white T-shirt with a phrase printed in the red and green colors of Italy’s flag: “Daddy’s Little Meatball.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Racism and Sexism Underlie Higher Maternal Death Rates for Black Women, U.N. Says
description: Black women in Latin America, the Caribbean and the United States are more likely than their white counterparts to report denial of medication or physical and verbal abuse in health care settings.
content: A new United Nations analysis of Black women’s experiences during pregnancy and childbirth in the Americas has concluded that systemic racism and sexism in medical systems — not genetics or lifestyle choices — are the main reasons they are more likely to experience serious complications or even death.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Russia Leaves Rotting Bodies and Old Socks
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 12, 2023.
content: “The soldiers will learn. It’s complicated. And yes, it’s going slowly. But importantly, it’s going.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Krysten Chambrot
title: 12 Easy, Budget-Friendly Pastas That Don’t Skimp on Flavor
description: Because eating well shouldn’t cost a fortune.
content: Pasta isn’t always thought of as an expensive meal, but when you add a lot of ingredients or a handful of more opulent ones, its price per serving can climb. But these smart pastas rely on only a few powerful ingredients — many of which you probably already have on hand — to keep flavors big and costs small. Because dinner doesn’t have to be pricey to be delicious and to feel luxurious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Biden Touts Easing Inflation as ‘Bidenomics in Action’
description: The White House has been making the case that the president’s policies have kept the economy on a steady path and maintained a healthy labor market.
content: President Biden, whose re-election prospects could hinge on whether inflation moderates without the economy tipping into a recession, quickly took credit for the latest data showing a June slowdown in price increases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Inflation Has Cooled Significantly
description: Also, Biden said NATO’s support for Ukraine “will not waver.” Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: The Consumer Price Index — the most widely used measure of inflation in the U.S. economy — climbed 3 percent in the year through June, according to new government data. That is sharply lower than the 9 percent rate at its peak a year ago, offering hope for both consumers and businesses that the recent era of inflated prices will soon be over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: On the Front Line of a War Over Bullfighting Traditions
description: Opponents of Spain’s comic shows at bullfights by people with dwarfism say they are banned by a new law. But performers say the show must go on.
content: After a nearly seven-hour journey, the bus carrying “The Popeye Bullfighter and his Dwarf Sailors” slowed to a stop around the brick bullfighting ring in Teruel. A brass band, clowns, children, wives, babies, the company’s leader and seven performers with achondroplasia, a bone growth disorder that causes the more common type of dwarfism, spilled out into the sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: ‘Barbie’ and ‘Oppenheimer’ Fans Are Ready for Their Double Feature
description: Some of the moviegoers planning on a “Barbenheimer” — seeing both on the same day — are relishing the incongruous subject matter of the two new releases.
content: One movie is bursting with life-size doll houses and blowout parties and so, so much pink. The other tells the origin story of the deadliest weapon in human history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Questions Surround Ukraine’s NATO Membership, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: For J. Smith-Cameron, ‘Succession’ Was ‘More Than the Sum of Its Parts’
description: The actor was one of many “Succession” stars to receive Emmy nominations on Wednesday. “But performances can only be as good as what’s written,” she said.
content: The world is her slime puppy now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Here’s What the Experts Say About Managing Putin
description: The Baltic countries got Russia right when much of the West got it wrong.
content: VILNIUS, Lithuania — Many Americans and Europeans flatter themselves by seeing the war in Ukraine through a false prism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Quick One-Pot Pasta to Make the Most of Summer Zucchini and Basil
description: Pair with Rebekah Peppler’s Tequila Soleil, a bright tequila Negroni topped off with crisp beer.
content: Hi! I’m back from vacation — rested, sunburned and extremely well-fed. Although cooking is part of my livelihood, it’s also my happy place, and a vacation gives me more time and head space to revel in it. I could take as much time as I liked dreaming up meal plans, experimenting with new ingredients, fussing over garnishes and cute little hors d’oeuvres.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: What’s Next for Israel’s Judicial Overhaul?
description: Critics of the government’s plan to limit the power of courts are wary of what they call “salami tactics,” slicing up the project into smaller pieces to make it more palatable to a wary public.
content: They call it “salami tactics.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Vandal Burns Major Public Artwork by One of Italy’s Top Living Artists
description: A man was detained in connection with the destruction of a monumental version of ‘Venus of the Rags’ by Michelangelo Pistoletto. City officials pledged the installation will rise again.
content: A vandal in Naples burned down a recently installed artwork by one of Italy’s most famous living artists, prompting outrage among residents along with a pledge by city officials that the piece would be replaced with a new version.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘The Last of Us’ Was Created ‘From a Place of Purity’
description: Craig Mazin, a creator of the Emmy-nominated HBO thriller, said it surpassed previous game adaptations because it was driven by passion rather than a desire to exploit a popular title.
content: The amount of pressure that came with trying to turn the dystopian video game “The Last of Us” into an HBO drama was intense: There were the expectations of tens of millions of fans of the best-selling game. The astronomical costs required — a reported production budget of more than $100 million — to pull it off. The legacy of dozens of subpar video game adaptations that had come before it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik and Margaret Lyons
title: Emmys: Our Critics on ‘Beef,’ ‘Succession’ and Category Confusion
description: The difference between comedy and drama is hazier than ever, as is the future of the Emmy Awards ceremony itself.
content: The 2023 Primetime Emmy nominations were announced on Wednesday. James Poniewozik and Margaret Lyons, two television critics for The New York Times, discussed who made it and who didn’t, the limp limited-series slate, reality TV blind spots and all those acting nominations for “Succession” and “The White Lotus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Agriculture Dept. to Invest $300 Million to Measure Greenhouse Emissions
description: The agency is seeking to better monitor greenhouse gases released through farming, which is responsible for about 10 percent of national emissions.
content: The Agriculture Department said on Wednesday that it would establish a monitoring and data collection network to measure greenhouse gas emissions and determine how much carbon can be captured using certain farming practices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: Apocalypse Nowish: Singing the Prophetic Warnings of Octavia Butler
description: Toshi Reagon and Bernice Johnson Reagon adapted Butler’s dystopian “Parable of the Sower.” Their opera makes its New York debut at Lincoln Center’s Summer for the City.
content: In Octavia Butler’s 1993 dystopian novel “Parable of the Sower,” the world is plagued by climate change, a refugee crisis, violent class warfare and the rise of a charismatic, evangelical leader who vows to “make America great again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Mooallem
title: A Royal Soldier Fainted in the Heat. It Holds a Lesson for All of Us.
description: Even as climate change upends our lives, we seem set on doing things the way we’ve always done them.
content: It was a dress rehearsal in which everyone seemed to be wearing the wrong clothes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Delayed by the Pandemic, Pilobolus Celebrates Its 50th
description: The company wraps up its delayed anniversary tour with a selection of vintage dances and premieres in a three-week season at the Joyce Theater.
content: Pilobolus has been pushing bodies to their limits in unusual shapes and precarious balances since 1971, when its founding members met at Dartmouth College. The company’s leadership has shifted and changed over the years, but what remains is the group’s collaborative approach. If a uniform mentality prevails — all for one and one for all — it’s partly because of the nature of its acrobatic, robust choreography. Strength is a must and so is trust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Woodrell
title: The House Is Off Limits and Haunted. Of Course We Have to Go In.
description: In “The Militia House,” by John Milas, an abandoned building in Afghanistan captivates and terrifies the Marines stationed nearby.
content: John Milas’s honest, sad and disturbing first novel, “The Militia House,” might be called gothic fiction or horror, but at heart it’s the story of one man’s struggle to maintain his grip on reality amid incessant conflict. Our narrator, Corporal Loyette, has joined the Marines primarily because his brother was killed by an I.E.D. while serving in Iraq. He doesn’t speak of revenge, but does have a sense that it is his duty to go, to see the elephant, to show his face on a battlefield of his own time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Zayn Malik Talks Life Since One Direction in His First Interview in Years
description: The “Pillowtalk” singer speaks candidly of his departure from the group: “We’d got sick of each other.”
content: After a hiatus from public life and interviews, Zayn Malik, the former One Direction member, appeared on a podcast that aired on Wednesday and talked about his decision to leave the group, what life has been like since then and his new single in his first interview in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: The Once and Future Climate Emergency
description: Heavy rains have caused catastrophic flooding and soaring temperatures are heating up oceans and cities. But emergency response often seems more popular than prevention on many issues.
content: Daily climate disasters are the new normal. In the past week, heavy rain on one side of the U.S. caused catastrophic flooding in New York and Vermont, and on the other side sent houses sliding off California mountains. The ocean off Florida has surface temperatures in the 90s Fahrenheit, and Arizonans have endured over-110-degree heat for more than a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: This Is One Republican Strategy That Isn’t Paying Off
description: Voter suppression isn’t what it’s cracked up to be.
content: In 2011, determined to push back the ascendant Democratic coalition that elected America’s first Black president, Republicans capitalized on their control of legislatures and governor’s mansions in 20 states to enact measures designed to suppress minority Democratic voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn and Elena Shao
title: How Hot Is the Sea Off Florida Right Now? Think 90s Fahrenheit.
description: Researchers are recording ocean temperatures that pose severe risks to coral reefs and other marine life.
content: Florida’s coral reefs are facing what could be an unprecedented threat from a marine heat wave that is warming the Gulf of Mexico, pushing water temperatures into the 90s Fahrenheit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
title: Chinese Hackers Targeted Commerce Secretary and Other U.S. Officials
description: The hackers took aim at specific email accounts in the State and Commerce Departments, officials said.
content: Chinese hackers penetrated the email accounts of Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo and other State and Commerce Department officials in the weeks before Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken traveled to Beijing in June, U.S. officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Flash Flooding Expected in Southern Arkansas and North Louisiana
description: The National Weather Service in Shreveport, La., warned that flash flooding could cause “a life-threatening situation.”
content: Several flash flood warnings were issued for parts of Arkansas and Louisiana on Wednesday morning, following days of destructive flooding across the Northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Demolition of House Where Idaho Students Were Killed Is Postponed
description: The college had planned to demolish the home where four students were fatally stabbed overnight in November.
content: The University of Idaho said on Wednesday that it would hold off on demolishing the house near its campus where four students were stabbed to death last fall, reversing its initial plan after pressure from some of the families of the victims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: The Puny Power of ‘Woke Capitalism’
description: Companies embrace progressive values to expand their market share while obscuring their raw political power.
content: Early last year, the musician India.Arie posted a video on her Instagram that caused a lot of headaches for my then-employer, Spotify. It was a mash-up of the many times Spotify’s star podcaster, Joe Rogan, had used a racial slur for Black people on his show. I don’t need to tell you which slur it was. Unsurprisingly, the video quickly went viral, and a huge uproar ensued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Glenn Thrush
title: House Republicans Criticize F.B.I. in Contentious Hearing
description: Stoked by former President Donald J. Trump, congressional Republicans have been trying to undermine the bureau’s legitimacy with the public.
content: Republicans bombarded Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, on Wednesday with criticisms about his role in investigating former President Donald J. Trump, efforts to address extremist violence and the bureau’s electronic surveillance practices during a contentious House Judiciary Committee hearing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Mikala Jones, Surfer Known for Photography Inside Waves, Is Dead
description: Mr. Jones was surfing on Sunday off the coast of Sumatra when the fin from his board cut an artery, The Associated Press reported.
content: Mikala Jones, a professional surfer known for his photography and videos filmed from inside the tight tubes of breaking waves, has died after an accident while he was surfing in Indonesia, his family said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Florida, an Ocean as Hot as Bath Water Is Threatening the Coral Reefs
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 13, 2023.
content: “Florida is one patch in a terrible quilt right now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Democrat’s Defection Gives Georgia G.O.P. First Black Woman in State House
description: But Mesha Mainor is now likely to face an uphill battle in holding onto her seat in a heavily Democratic district in Atlanta.
content: A Democrat who represents part of Atlanta in Georgia’s House of Representatives defected to the Republican Party on Tuesday, saying she was subject to a campaign of intimidation by onetime political allies after breaking with them on school vouchers, policing and prosecutorial oversight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: 2,000 Miles, a Balky R.V. and a Swim with Whale Sharks: How We Got Our Travel Mojo Back
description: A pandemic-delayed journey to Australia’s Ningaloo Reef helped a family regain its belief in the serendipity of the open road.
content: All we wanted after a magnificent snorkeling session off the coast of Western Australia was for the stupid motor home to start, to stop grinding away with that almost-but-not-today sound that made our hearts race faster than the engine. Bertie, as we called the 21-foot recreational vehicle we had rented, sounded like she wanted to work. She just lacked the energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Sound of Freedom’ Review: In the Land of Child Traffickers
description: Starring Jim Caviezel, this movie tells a story of child trafficking and the people combating it. But its muted tone ultimately undercuts its solemn sense of mission.
content: The first 30 minutes or so of this picture are queasy for several reasons. After announcing itself as based on true events, “Sound of Freedom” depicts its hero, the Homeland Security agent Tim Ballard, apprehending a pedophile. Another agent, discussing their line of work and musing that “it’s a messed up world,” wonders why they’re not rescuing the children peddled by traffickers. Ballard, played by Jim Caviezel, gets a notion. He coddles the pedophile and sets up a sting. This nets him just one child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Maggie Haberman
title: DeSantis Confronts a Murdoch Empire No Longer Quite So Supportive
description: The Florida governor has faced tough questions and critical coverage lately from Fox News and other conservative outlets, in a sign of growing skepticism.
content: In March, as Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida laid the groundwork for his presidential run, he joined the Fox News host Brian Kilmeade to play a nationally televised game of catch on his hometown baseball field outside Tampa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Jeremy W. Peters
title: Arizona Man Cited in Conspiracy Theories Sues Fox News for Defamation
description: Ray Epps, a two-time Trump voter, says Tucker Carlson repeatedly and falsely named him as a covert government agent who incited the Jan. 6 attack.
content: Ray Epps, the man at the center of a widespread conspiracy theory about the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, filed a lawsuit on Wednesday accusing Fox News and its former host Tucker Carlson of defamation for promoting a “fantastical story” that Mr. Epps was an undercover government agent who instigated the violence at the Capitol as a way to disparage President Donald J. Trump and his supporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Ruth Igielnik
title: G.O.P. Led in Midterm Turnout, a Red Flag for Democrats in 2024
description: Even though Democrats held the Senate and other key offices, Republican turnout was more robust, and the party showed strength among women, Latinos and rural voters, a new report found.
content: Even though Democrats held off a widely expected red wave in the 2022 midterm elections, Republican turnout was in fact stronger, and the party energized key demographic groups including women, Latinos and rural voters, according to a report released Wednesday by the Pew Research Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: In ‘The Lesson,’ It’s a Bad Writer Who Steals
description: Richard E. Grant and Daryl McCormack star as writers with similar source material in a feature tracing the limits of literary authorship.
content: In “The Lesson,” an amusingly taut British thriller playing now in American movie theaters, two novels result from the same events at an opulent country estate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: In ‘Poker Face,’ Natasha Lyonne Just Wants to Give You Some Truth
description: Lyonne’s role as a human lie detector earned her an Emmy nomination for acting, her third. It also let her experiment with a beloved archetype: part Peter Falk, part “desert rat.”
content: In the Peacock murder-of-the-week procedural “Poker Face,” Natasha Lyonne plays Charlie Cale, a former cocktail waitress and poker hustler with a difference: Charlie is a human lie detector in a trucker hat, able to spot a falsehood from across the casino floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: ‘I’m Not a No. 2 Guy’: DeSantis Says He Wouldn’t Run as Trump’s Vice President
description: It is far too soon to speculate about who will be the Republican nominee for vice president, but a Trump-DeSantis ticket seems highly unlikely.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida said on Tuesday that he would not be interested in running as former President Donald J. Trump’s vice president, if Mr. Trump does win the 2024 nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Alan Ruck Is Happy That Connor Roy Survived
description: At one point disappointed by his character’s spare role in “Succession,” Ruck’s patience was rewarded with a meaty final season, and now, an Emmy nomination.
content: As HBO’s media-dynasty drama “Succession” was wrapping up its final season, Alan Ruck, the actor who plays the oblivious and often ignored eldest son, Connor Roy, admitted that he had once felt so unsatisfied with his depth of material that he suggested to the show’s top brass that his character be killed off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Therapy Where the Clothes Come Off (Sometimes)
description: By combining talk therapy with elements of physical touch, surrogate partners assist people who struggle with sex and intimacy.
content: Eileen Chao works with people who, for any number of reasons, are less than comfortable with sex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Friends Excluded Me From Their Awesome Trip. What Should I Do?
description: A reader ponders her next move after being left out of vacation plans with four other women.
content: I am part of a friend group with four other women. They are going on an amazing international trip and didn’t invite me. I have traveled successfully with one of the women and less successfully with the organizer of the trip. (That led to some distance between us, which we have since repaired.) I am really hurt and deflated by my exclusion. I love to travel, but my partner can’t afford trips like this, so I rely on my friends as travel partners. I also like and respect these women, even if they’re not my closest friends. But this experience makes me feel that I’m not important to any of them. What’s my best move? Talk to the organizer? Confront each of them? Or back away from the group?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard J. Evans
title: The Holocaust in Poland and the Erasures of the Past
description: In “Jews in the Garden,” the journalist Judy Rakowsky helps a relative uncover the truth of what happened to their family during World War II.
content: Three decades ago, the veteran reporter Judy Rakowsky began accompanying her elderly relative Sam on trips to Eastern Europe. Sam had survived the ghettos and camps of the Holocaust in Nazi-occupied Poland and Germany. He performed forced labor in a factory, as did an aunt and uncle who were among the Jews employed by Oskar Schindler, the German industrialist made famous in Steven Spielberg’s movie “Schindler’s List.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen and Mike Isaac
title: Threads Review: How Meta’s New App Stacks Up Against Twitter
description: One of us is a Twitter addict; the other not so much. In the end, we were both unsure how people might use Threads in the long run.
content: When we — Brian X. Chen and Mike Isaac, both longtime tech journalists — got an assignment from our editor last week to review Threads, the new social network from Meta, it was like a blast from the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: A Finnish Official Plays the Cello to Support Ukraine, Irking Russia
description: Anders Adlercreutz’s recording of a patriotic Ukrainian song was widely circulated online, and prompted a response from Moscow.
content: Anders Adlercreutz, Finland’s minister for European affairs, has long been a critic of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, denouncing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for leading a “crazy war” and calling on Western governments to send tanks to Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: Logan Paul’s Prime Energy Drink Under Scrutiny Over High Caffeine Content
description: Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, has asked the F.D.A. to investigate a popular beverage created by the YouTube influencers Logan Paul and KSI over its high caffeine content.
content: The release of Prime, a drink brand founded by the YouTube personality and boxer Logan Paul, had British teenagers lining up for hours outside grocery stores on its release date in December.  Some supermarkets were even forced to limit purchases to one bottle per customer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Victor Moriyama
title: How a Peaceful Country Became a Gold Rush State for Drug Cartels
description: In Ecuador, an intelligence official said: “People consume abroad, but they don’t understand the consequences that take place here.”
content: A total of 210 tons of drugs seized in a single year, a record. At least 4,500 killings last year, also a record. Children recruited by gangs. Prisons as hubs for crime. Neighborhoods consumed by criminal feuds. And all this chaos financed by powerful outsiders with deep pockets and lots of experience in the global drug business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Turning Point for Military Spending
description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has led to a new willingness for countries to pay for their own defense.
content: NATO countries have been promising to spend more money on defense for many years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: The Easiest Salted Caramel Ice Cream Doesn’t Require a Machine
description: Whipped cream and store-bought dulce de leche are all you need for this frozen summer treat.
content: When you urgently need a frozen treat without leaving the house to get it, the most satisfying shortcut might be a cold and fluffy no-churn ice cream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Mayor’s Response to Wildfire Smoke Was Sluggish, New York Officials Say
description: At a City Council oversight hearing, the Adams administration defended its handling of the air quality emergency, saying that the conditions were worse than predicted.
content: As a carpet of acrid smoke darkened New York City’s skies and turned them orange last month, many New Yorkers looked to their city’s leaders for immediate guidance on how to stay safe, but were frustrated when they received none.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Adler-Bell
title: The Essential John le Carré
description: His clever, melancholic mind produced some of the most enduring heroes in spy fiction. Here are his best books.
content: The English novelist John le Carré (given name: David Cornwell) never sufficiently explained his nom de plume. Of course, we know why he needed one: He still worked for MI6, the British equivalent of the C.I.A., when he wrote his first three books. For years, he told reporters that he’d glimpsed the name on a storefront while riding a bus. That was a lie, he later admitted, a “tiny deception operation” devised to conceal an even more banal truth: that he just couldn’t remember. “I just got sick of saying, ‘I don’t know where it came from,’” he confessed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Amazon Prime Day, Walmart Plus Week and the Battle of the Retail Giants
description: America’s two largest private employers have converged in some ways, but each still has a leg up on the other.
content: When titans clash, the ground shakes and televisions get a lot cheaper. I’m referring, of course, to this week’s Christmas-in-July sales competition between Walmart and Amazon, the biggest and second-biggest private employers in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Community Land Trusts in California Work to Create New Homeowners
description: The state’s 30 or so land trusts sell houses at a discount, helping buyers who would otherwise be priced out.
content: Buying a house in California below the market sounds too good to be true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Michael D. Regan
title: Manhattan Cannabis Chain Raided by Police and State Agents
description: Empire Cannabis Club is the target of stepped-up state efforts to crack down on unlicensed shops.
content: New York Police Department officers and state tax agents raided one Manhattan dispensary and were thwarted from raiding another on Tuesday in an exercise of their newly expanded powers to crack down on unlicensed cannabis shops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Murderer Released in Secretive Deal Is Recaptured After Months on the Run
description: A call to a tip line led the authorities to a New York City apartment, where they found a South Carolina man believed to be wrongly freed from prison.
content: The manhunt for a convicted murderer who left a South Carolina prison under puzzling circumstances pressed on for more than two months with few developments. The reward for his capture kept growing, climbing to $60,000, as the authorities made repeated pleas for help. He was dangerous, they warned, and he could be anywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Braces NATO for Long Conflict With Russia, Making Cold War Parallel
description: Concluding a NATO summit focused on the war in Ukraine and other fast-changing challenges, President Biden vowed that the alliance would oppose Russian aggression for as long as needed.
content: President Biden concluded a meeting of NATO allies on Wednesday in Vilnius, Lithuania, with an address to that country, and the world, comparing the battle to expel Russia from Ukraine with the Cold War struggle for freedom in Europe, and promising “we will not waver” no matter how long the war continues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Royal Caribbean Bets on a Giant Candy-Colored Cruise Ship
description: The ship, by some measures the world’s largest, will depart from Miami in January on its maiden voyage. Some can’t wait to board. Others call it a “monstrosity” that is bad for the environment.
content: When the Icon of the Seas sets sail early next year, it will take some time to disappear from the horizon. At 1,198 feet long and a gross tonnage of 250,800, it is hard to miss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: E.P.A. Proposes Tighter Limits on Lead Dust in Homes and Child Care Facilities
description: Under the proposed rules, any amount of lead dust in floors and window sills would qualify as “hazardous” and require abatement.
content: The Biden administration on Wednesday proposed to strengthen requirements for the removal of lead-based paint dust in homes and child care facilities built before 1978, an effort to eliminate exposure to lead that could require millions of property owners to pay for abatement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Top News Anchor Is Identified as Person Suspended by the BBC
description: The wife of Huw Edwards, one of the BBC’s most prominent figures, said in a statement that her husband suffered from mental health issues. The police said there was no evidence of a crime.
content: The BBC staff member suspended on allegations of sexual misconduct was identified by his wife on Wednesday as Huw Edwards, an anchor on the BBC’s flagship nightly news program and one of its most prominent and distinguished figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Hiba Yazbek
title: Palestinian Leader Visits City Israel Raided, Trying to Signal Strength
description: In the city of Jenin, partly dominated by militias, Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority president, was seen as a relic and treated as a guest, not a ruler.
content: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority made his first visit in years to Jenin, the battle-scarred and impoverished Palestinian city in the north of the Israeli-occupied West Bank that was the target of a two-day raid by the Israeli military last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: How to Revive a Dying Main Street? One U.K. Landlord Offered Free Rent.
description: In a coastal English town, a floundering shopping district was given new life after 10 local businesses were given free rent for two years.
content: For two decades, Steven Wyatt was in a cycle of drug addiction and rehab. In 2006, during a stint at a recovery center, he learned how to restore furniture, a skill that led him to an unexpected place: running his own store in Poole, a coastal town in southwest England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dawn Chan
title: Call It Dance, Puppetry or Sculpture, It Is Eerily Beautiful
description: Throughout the 21-minute arc of “Divine Generations,” a silent four-person ensemble pulls cords around the room, coaxing inert discs into motion.
content: A classic marionette might have eight to 10 strings. Leah Ogawa’s latest puppet, an ethereal tree-shaped form, has more than 600: clustered into thickets and tangles, threaded through eye bolts on the ceiling, and fanning out overhead to all corners of the room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: G.O.P.’s Far Right Seeks to Use Defense Bill to Defund Ukraine War Effort
description: The group’s proposals have no chance of passage, but they have further mired the military spending bill in a partisan fight and highlighted Republican divisions over the war.
content: A group of right-wing House Republicans pushing to load up the annual defense bill with socially conservative policies on abortion, race and gender have another demand: severe restrictions on U.S. military support for Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: From 400 Feet Above, a Lake’s Algae Problems Look Clear
description: To understand the challenges at Lake Okeechobee, a vast inland sea in Florida, The New York Times piloted a drone.
content: Lake Okeechobee, in South Florida, has a problem that grows every summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Elyssa Dudley, Hans Buetow, Jen Poyant, Sara Sarasohn, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Sonia Herrero, Pat McCusker and Carole Sabouraud
title: The Day My Family Changed Forever
description: The youngest Modern Love essayist shares a story of divorce from the child’s perspective. And then we hear from listeners about the moment their parents’ divorce became real for them.
content: Imagine you are on vacation. Your favorite shirt is waiting for you in your suitcase. You go to put it on, only to realize it’s not there. You forgot it, and there’s nothing you can do now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In Milan Kundera’s Work, the Erotic Meets the Subversive
description: His best novels, charged with a distrust of authority, retain their sweep and power.
content: It’s hard to overstate how central Milan Kundera was, in the mid-1980s, to literary culture in America and elsewhere. He was the best-known Czech writer since Kafka, and his fiction brought news of sophisticated Eastern European societies trembling under the threat of Soviet repression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Airfares tumble, helping bring down overall inflation.
description: Ticket prices are subject to several idiosyncratic factors, but they have eased markedly since last summer’s surge in demand.
content: Airfares took another dive last month, following a wild ride over the past year, reflecting volatile energy prices and swings in demand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Achauer and Zack Wittman
title: The Full-Body Pool Workout That Doesn’t Involve Swimming
description: This 20-minute aquatic exercise routine is easy on the joints and provides a fun alternative to the gym, especially in summer.
content: When Kelly Amerson López discovered aquatic exercise, it was nothing like she expected. She was in her 30s and a fitness buff who ran half marathons in Central Park. One day at the gym, she stumbled upon a group of people using the pool. They were running in place and pivoting in chest-deep water, and the instructor sounded more like a drill sergeant than a water aerobics teacher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Chinese Hackers Breached Government Email Accounts, Microsoft Says
description: The hack, by a Chinese group that the company said was intent on conducting espionage, went undetected for a month.
content: Chinese hackers intent on collecting intelligence on the United States gained access to government email accounts, Microsoft disclosed on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Bob Iger to Remain as Head of Disney Through 2026
description: The 72-year-old chief executive previously said he planned to leave a the end of his contract in 2024.
content: Robert A. Iger has extended his reign at Disney through 2026, as finding an heir continues to be difficult and questions mount about the viability of the company’s vaunted movie studios and theme parks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: This Fried-Zucchini Pasta Took Three Generations to Perfect
description: Capers and pistachios play on a tradition from Yotam Ottolenghi’s family.
content: If I had to pick one central food memory of my childhood, it is my grandmother’s Passover Seder, where a humble plate of fried zucchini — a culinary relic from 1920s Italy in 1980s Israel — was what everyone gravitated toward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Despite Successes at NATO Summit, Divisions Remain
description: The alliance added Sweden, laid out new ambitions for itself and offered long-term support for Ukraine, promising membership someday. But Kyiv wanted more.
content: VILNIUS, Lithuania — NATO had some significant successes at its summit that ended Wednesday as it worked hard to project unity in support of Ukraine’s bloody defense against Russia’s invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Jessica Williams Celebrated her Emmy Nomination on the Picket Line
description: The “Shrinking” star discussed her first nomination while picketing outside Disney. “It’s a crazy day today,” she said. “I have to stand in solidarity.”
content: A therapist will often begin a session by asking how a patient feels today. For Jessica Williams, the answer on Wednesday afternoon was multilayered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: With writers on strike (and actors possibly right behind them), it’s an awkward time for Emmy nominations.
description: The normally joyous affair of toasting television’s best is happening while much of Hollywood is shut down.
content: More than 11,000 television and feature film writers have been on strike for 72 days. The union representing 160,000 actors has been in negotiations with the major Hollywood studios for over a month — and could declare a strike as soon as its contract expires late Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: What to Know About Vermont’s Devastating Floods
description: Forecasters are warning of more rain in the coming days after the state was inundated by a deluge.
content: After a powerful storm that dumped as much as nine inches of rain on parts of Vermont, residents in cities and towns across the state are only beginning to grapple with the destruction caused by the flooding unleashed by the deluge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I Dated a Celebrity. Do I Have to Tell My Wife?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on revealing a past romance to a current partner.
content: I’ve been married for nearly 40 years, and for no particular reason, neither my wife nor I felt compelled to share much about our prior love lives. There was nothing much noteworthy to share on my part, but that changed about three years into the marriage. A young woman with whom I had a summer-long relationship as a teenager was beginning to make waves in the music industry — waves that would continue to the point where her music is now instantly recognizable to most people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Shannon Lin, Carlos Prieto, Michael Simon Johnson, Lisa Chow, Marc Georges, Marion Lozano and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Great Resignation is Over
description: Over the past two years, tens of millions of Americans have quit their jobs. Now, that seems to be ending.
content: Tens of millions of Americans changed jobs over the past two years, a rare moment of worker power as employees demanded higher pay, and as employers, short on staff, often gave it to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Who Should Be Tracking Their Glucose?
description: Continuous glucose monitors are essential for people with diabetes. For everyone else, it’s more complicated.
content: Monitoring blood sugar levels used to be something only people with diabetes did. But in recent years, glucose has become one of the trendiest biometrics to track for people striving to optimize their health. That’s in large part because of the increasing accessibility of a tool called a continuous glucose monitor, or C.G.M.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Floods, Heat, Smoke: The Weather Will Never Be Normal Again
description: Global warming is accelerating, and it’s starting to show.
content: Global warming is accelerating, with temperatures not just rising but rising faster than ever. Every day, it seems, we get better at normalizing extreme weather. But it is simultaneously proving harder to compartmentalize — even in places such as New York City that once looked to residents like concrete fortresses against nature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: The Shed Hires Its New C.E.O. From Boston Ballet
description: As the new arts space faces financial challenges, it tapped Meredith Hodges to take over its administrative leadership from Alex Poots, who will remain as artistic director.
content: After a mixed beginning that was complicated by the coronavirus pandemic, the Shed in Manhattan’s Hudson Yards announced Wednesday that it had tapped Meredith Hodges, known as Max, the executive director of the Boston Ballet, to become its new chief executive officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Translating Traditional Korean Movement to ‘a Language for Our Time’
description: “One Dance,” part of Korean Arts Week at Lincoln Center, puts a contemporary spin on rituals and ceremonies.
content: Like many court ceremonies, the Confucian ritual that has been performed for centuries at the royal Jongmyo shrine in Korea, is meticulous and measured, stately and restrained. In the shrine’s stone courtyard, a large group of women stand in place, arranged in rows, holding symbolic objects like bamboo flutes and wooden swords and periodically shifting the position of their arms in perfect, unhurried unison. This part is called il mu, which can be translated as “line dance” or “one dance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: A Revival of ‘The Who’s Tommy’ Seeks a New Generation of Followers
description: In staging the storied rock opera in Chicago, its creators argue that the show’s exploration of celebrity worship and childhood trauma is more relevant than ever.
content: Thirty years ago, when the Who’s 1969 concept album “Tommy” was transformed into a rock opera for Broadway, it was hailed as a triumph of the form — a production that had finally managed to authentically marry theater and rock ’n’ roll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: ‘Succession’ propels HBO to huge haul of nominations.
description: “Succession,” HBO’s operatic saga about a media dynasty and a two-time best drama winner, scored 27 Emmy nominations for its farewell season on Wednesday morning, the biggest haul of any series. Here’s what to know:
content: “Succession,” HBO’s operatic saga about a media dynasty and a two-time best drama winner, scored 27 Emmy nominations for its farewell season on Wednesday morning, the biggest haul of any series. Here’s what to know:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: Russian Military Hit by Uncertainty as One General Is Killed and Another Remains Absent
description: A Russian lawmaker says that Gen. Sergei Surovikin, who has not been seen in public since a short-lived mutiny, has been “taking a rest.”
content: One top commander has disappeared since a mutiny. Another was killed in an airstrike in Ukraine. Another accused his leadership of treachery after being fired. And a fourth former commander was gunned down while out on a jog in what may have been an organized hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Catrin Einhorn
title: After a Bitter Fight, European Lawmakers Pass a Bill to Repair Nature
description: The measure would require E.U. countries to restore damaged natural habitats.
content: European lawmakers, after an unexpectedly bitter political battle, approved a bill on Wednesday that would require European Union countries to restore 20 percent of all degraded nature areas within their borders on land and at sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Ohio Plastic Surgeon Loses Medical License After TikTok Livestreams
description: The State Medical Board of Ohio voted on Wednesday to revoke Katharine Roxanne Grawe’s medical license after she broadcast some patients’ procedures.
content: An Ohio plastic surgeon lost her medical license on Wednesday after the state medical board investigated her for livestreaming operations on TikTok and surgical complications reported by patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: This, That or Whichever
description: Brooke Husic and Brian Thomas help us pass the time.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex W. Palmer
title: ‘An Act of War’: Inside America’s Silicon Blockade Against China
description: The Biden administration thinks it can preserve America’s technological primacy by cutting China off from advanced computer chips. Could the plan backfire?
content: Last October, the United States Bureau of Industry and Security issued a document that — underneath its 139 pages of dense bureaucratic jargon and minute technical detail — amounted to a declaration of economic war on China. The magnitude of the act was made all the more remarkable by the relative obscurity of its source. One of 13 bureaus within the Department of Commerce, the smallest federal department by funding, B.I.S. is tiny: Its budget for 2022 was just over $140 million, about one-eighth the cost of a single Patriot air-defense missile battery. The bureau employs approximately 350 agents and officers, who collectively monitor trillions of dollars’ worth of transactions taking place all around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: The Glamorous Stranger Next Door Knew Everyone. And She Needed Help.
description: The mysterious neighbor claimed to have witnessed a nuclear detonation, marched on Selma and acted on Broadway. Would an overlooked form letter be her downfall?
content: Tina Dupuy was, and was going to be, a lot of different things — a standup comic, a political columnist, the host of a podcast about cults, a congressman’s communications director on Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: E.R. Visits for Teenage Girls Surged During the Pandemic
description: The proportion of teen girls visiting emergency rooms in mental health crisis rose 22 percent in the pandemic’s second year, while the proportion of teen boys visiting declined.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic dragged through its second year, an increasing number of American families were so desperate to get help for depressed or suicidal children that they brought them to emergency rooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Lewis
title: Milan Kundera, Literary Star Who Skewered Communist Rule, Dies at 94
description: The author of “The Unbearable Lightness of Being,” he was known for sexually charged novels that captured the suffocating absurdity of life in his native Czechoslovakia.
content: Milan Kundera, the Communist Party outcast who became a global literary star with mordant, sexually charged novels that captured the suffocating absurdity of life in the workers’ paradise of his native Czechoslovakia, died on Tuesday in Paris. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 12, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, July 12, 2023.
content: An article on Sunday about the collapse of the Dutch coalition government over a proposed refugee policy referred imprecisely to Jan Paternotte’s role in the D66 party. He leads the party in the House of Representatives, not the party overall. The error was repeated in an article on Tuesday about the Dutch prime minister Mark Rutte’s exit from politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Penn Station Is a Disgrace. Can a New Plan Improve It?
description: A private firm’s proposal for the station tries to restore some of its old romance, unlike the M.T.A. plan, our architecture critic says.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll hear from The Times’s architecture critic on something that would change the look of a much-traveled stretch of Midtown Manhattan, inside and out — a plan for a new Pennsylvania Station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: Football Superfan Caught in California and Charged in $70,000 Bank Theft
description: Federal prosecutors accused Xaviar Babudar, a Kansas City Chiefs fan known as ChiefsAholic, of committing a string of bank robberies across the Midwest.
content: As the Kansas City Chiefs’ main hype man, Xaviar Babudar, known by fans as ChiefsAholic, attended nearly every game, at home and away. Given the hefty price of football tickets, it was a high-flying lifestyle, which Mr. Babudar attributed to successful warehouses he managed across the Midwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Iverson
title: Easy Mode: Clues for Friday, July 14, 2023
description: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
content: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Cools Sharply in June, Good News for Consumers and the Fed
description: The Consumer Price Index climbed far more slowly in June, a relief for shoppers and a hopeful — though inconclusive — sign that America might pull off a “soft landing.”
content: Inflation cooled significantly in June, offering some of the most hopeful news since the Federal Reserve began trying to tame rapid price increases 16 months ago — and boosting the chances that the central bank might be able to stop raising interest rates after its meeting this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Fauzia
title: Saber-Tooth Cats and Dire Wolves Carried a Terrible Disease in Their Bones
description: Researchers say that evidence of osteochondrosis dissecans in the ice age predators offers insights to how they went extinct.
content: Some 50,000 to 10,000 years ago as ice sheets melted and the planet warmed, around 100 species of gigantic animals started to disappear without a trace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Emmy Nominees 2023: The Complete List
description: The 75th Emmy Awards ceremony is planned for Sept. 18, but it may be delayed because of the Hollywood writers’ strike.
content: [Follow live updates of the 2023 Emmy nominations here.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: How Steven Soderbergh and Ed Solomon Straightened Out ‘Full Circle’
description: Their new crime thriller for Max is loaded with twists and layers. But it is actually much simpler than what they originally conceived.
content: The first time the director Steven Soderbergh and the screenwriter Ed Solomon worked together was on the murder mystery “Mosaic” (2017), which could be watched as a choose-your-own-adventure-style story using a smartphone app or as a six-episode HBO mini-series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: An Unlikely Hero Emerges to End an All-Star Losing Streak
description: The stage was set for Julio Rodríguez of the Mariners to deliver a win in Seattle. Instead, the National League got its first win since 2012 thanks to Elias Díaz.
content: If he could have scaled Mount Rainier to spread the message from on high, Rob Manfred surely would have. Manfred, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, had reason to celebrate his sport on Tuesday: attendance is up eight percent over last season, with a brisker pace of play, more daring on the bases, improving television ratings and surprise contenders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Conservative Group Withdraws Lawsuit Against Left-Wing Podcast
description: Young America’s Foundation had filed a suit against the podcast “Know Your Enemy,” saying the satirical use of the phrase “Young Americans for Freedom” violated its trademark.
content: Over the past four years, the podcast “Know Your Enemy” has built an avid following with its learned, irreverent promise to guide listeners “through the swampy morass of the American right.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: In Cities and Small Towns, Vermonters Reckon With the Devastation of Flooding
description: Calls for search and rescue missions continued, as residents and business owners started assessing damage, fueling an anxious, unsettled mood.
content: As floodwaters began to ebb on Tuesday, and Vermonters reckoned with the devastation of a record-breaking storm, shock mixed with a growing sense of dread at the long recovery ahead — and with a lingering uneasiness that more losses might yet be uncovered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Daniel Radcliffe Has an Emmy Nod, But His Accordion Skills Are Fading
description: The “Harry Potter” star received his first Emmy nomination on Wednesday, for “Weird: The Al Yankovic Story.” “A parody of biopics is the only thing a Weird Al biopic could ever be,” Radcliffe said.
content: It was a typical morning for Daniel Radcliffe when he got a not-so-typical call: He’d been nominated for his first Emmy Award, for best lead actor in a limited or anthology series or movie, for his performance as the parodist Weird Al Yankovic in last year’s Roku biopic “Weird: The Al Yankovic Story.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Britney Spears’s Wembanyama Run-In and Taylor Swift’s ‘Revenge’
description: Plus: Lil Uzi Vert’s new No. 1 “Pink Tape,” and Wes Anderson’s “Asteroid City.”
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Biden Vowed to Bring Gershkovich Home, His Parents Say
description: The parents of Evan Gershkovich, the American reporter jailed in Russia, said in a broadcast interview that President Biden had promised to do “whatever it takes” to secure his release.
content: When she was told where her son was being held, Ella Milman immediately recognized the name. Like many former residents of the Soviet Union, she knew about the Moscow prison’s chilling notoriety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: A Year of Cosmic Wonder With the James Webb Space Telescope
description: With a new image, NASA commemorates the first anniversary of doing science with the most powerful observatory ever sent to space.
content: By now, perhaps, we should be getting used to unreal images of the cosmos made with the James Webb Space Telescope. But a year after NASA released the cosmic observatory’s first imagery, the space agency has dropped yet another breathtaking snapshot of our universe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Bradley
title: Mushrooms Have Taken Over Fashion and Wellness. Up Next: Chocolate
description: A new wave of confections are harnessing the ancient pairing of fungi and cacao (without the hallucinogenic effects).
content: In H. G. Wells’s 1896 short story “The Purple Pileus,” the protagonist attempts to end his life by ingesting fungi; instead of death, he is met with psychedelic visions that help him improve his life. Mushrooms, in the literary imagination and in our physical world, have long been seen as a tool for change — at a point when a person can go no further, these powerful organisms can illuminate an alternate path. And their strength isn’t limited to the psychedelic: Functional mushrooms — species that have been shown to have cognitive, immune system and longevity benefits — have been used for centuries in Chinese medicine to treat a variety of ailments. The second-century text “Shen Nong Ben Cao Jing,” attributed to the mythological Chinese ruler Shen Nong, suggests that reishi mushrooms “may make the body light, prevent senility and prolong life so as to make one an immortal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Janelle James Reacts in Character to Emmy Nod: ‘This Is Expected’
description: James, who plays the brash Ava Coleman in “Abbott Elementary,” channeled her character’s thoughts on the nomination. (The real James was more impressed.)
content: To many television viewers, Janelle James has become synonymous with Ava Coleman, her bumbling but brashly confident elementary school principal in the hit ABC workplace comedy “Abbott Elementary.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Review: To Revisit a Sexual Assault, She Drugs Herself Onstage
description: In an ethically murky show at the Avignon Festival, the Brazilian performer Carolina Bianchi opens up about how she was drugged and abused, then knocks herself out with a spiked cocktail.
content: A decade ago, the Brazilian performer and director Carolina Bianchi was drugged and assaulted. In “The Bride and the Goodnight Cinderella” (“A Noiva e o Boa Noite Cinderela”), her new stage production at the Avignon Festival in France, she doesn’t merely open up about that experience. She relives part of it, night after night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: How Colleges Can Propel More People Into the Middle Class
description: We need policies that make higher education a better investment for more students.
content: In the two weeks since the Supreme Court rejected affirmative action in college admissions, there’s been a lot of talk about the racial makeup of elite institutions like Harvard and the University of North Carolina, the respondents in the case. And yes, the makeup of the student bodies at the most selective schools matters: Graduates of these institutions often have a certain level of access at the highest levels of business and government — the justices themselves are evidence of that. But the vast majority of American college students don’t attend these elite schools, and the rise of lower-income and nonwhite students in the undergraduate ranks has been “most pronounced in public two-year colleges and the least selective four-year colleges and universities.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Ann Hinga Klein
title: Asa Hutchinson Makes Pitch as Bigger Names and Personalities Crowd Him Out
description: Over pizzas or coffee, former Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas is talking to Iowans, six or eight at a time, in a fight to get into the Republican debates and stay in the race.
content: Holding court in a Pizza Ranch restaurant on Tuesday in Newton, Iowa, Asa Hutchinson was trying to keep his long-shot presidential bid aloft as formidable Republican heavyweights continued to dominate the state’s attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Mozambican Accused in $2 Billion ‘Tuna’ Scandal Is Extradited to New York
description: Manuel Chang, the former finance minister of Mozambique, is at the center of a scandal that roped in American investors.
content: The former finance minister of Mozambique, accused of helping orchestrate a financial corruption scandal that nearly caused the collapse of his nation’s economy and defrauded American investors, was extradited to the United States from South Africa on Wednesday to face charges in Federal District Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Tony Gilroy Kept the Faith for ‘Andor.’ Its 8 Emmy Nods Are Affirmation.
description: The show’s creator talked about the pressures and uncertainties of doing something different in the “Star Wars” universe — and seeing it pay off.
content: Wednesday was a big day for the Galactic Empire. “Andor,” the Disney+ “Star Wars” prequel series that made its debut last fall, picked up eight Emmy nominations, including one in the best drama category.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Folk
title: In These Four Story Collections, Feminist Horror Abounds
description: New short fiction by Agustina Bazterrica, Joyce Carol Oates, Nishanth Injam and Kathleen Alcott.
content: “She was horrified by the traces of monstrosity in everyday life,” Agustina Bazterrica writes of a character in her new collection, NINETEEN CLAWS AND A BLACKBIRD: Stories (Scribner, 154 pp., paperback, $17.99), and it could be read as a unifying principle for all 20 stories. Her breakout novel, “Tender Is the Flesh,” depicted a world in which humans are bred for meat, and while these tales trade in the macabre, they’re set in a universe that’s distinctly ours, lending them a subtler, more insidious resonance. Moses’ translation from the Spanish captures the playful gruesomeness of the Argentine writer’s prose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.1 Million Homes in Kentucky, Texas and Pennsylvania
description: An 1888 Queen Anne Revival house in Versailles, a Craftsman bungalow in Denton and a split-level home in New Hope.
content: This house is near the city center, a few blocks from the public library on Main Street and half a block from the Woodford County Historical Society. It is across the street from Big Spring Park and about five minutes from a public elementary school. The Woodford Reserve Distillery and Wild Turkey Distillery, popular stops on the Kentucky Bourbon Trail, are less than 15 minutes away by car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: John Koblin
title: HBO’s ‘Succession’ Dominates Emmy Nominations in Uncertain Year
description: Its final season earned 27 nods, the most of any drama, while “Ted Lasso” got 21, the most of any comedy. But the writers’ strike could delay the ceremony, planned for September.
content: “Succession,” HBO’s operatic saga about a media dynasty and a two-time best drama winner, scored 27 Emmy nominations for its farewell season on Wednesday morning, the biggest haul of any series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Almost $80 Billion Needed for Repairs to New York City’s Public Housing
description: The staggering estimate is a roughly 70 percent increase from the last calculation, in 2017, underscoring the New York City Housing Authority’s ballooning crisis.
content: New York City’s public housing agency now needs more than $78 billion to repair or renovate aging kitchens, leaky pipes, faulty elevators and other problems over the next 20 years, officials revealed on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: We Can’t Just Shoot Our Way Out of This
description: The “uphill battle” for guns isn’t over.
content: Our topic today is gun regulation. Come on, stop beating your head against the backyard grill. That thing’s hot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Biden Vows Not to ‘Waver’ After NATO Summit
description: Also, Chinese hackers hit the State Department, ocean temperatures rise and Milan Kundera dies.
content: President Biden concluded the meeting of NATO allies by comparing the battle to expel Russia from Ukraine with the Cold War struggle for freedom in Europe. “We will not waver,” he promised in a speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Hard Right Presses Culture War Fights on Defense Bill, Imperiling Passage
description: Right-wing Republicans want to use the annual military budget and policy legislation, traditionally a bipartisan affair, as a tool to pick fights on abortion and other social issues.
content: Hard-right House Republicans are pushing to use the yearly bill that sets the United States military budget and policy as an opportunity to pick fights with the Biden administration over abortion, race and transgender issues, imperiling its passage and the decades-old bipartisan consensus in Congress around backing the Pentagon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Man in Sweden Set to Burn Religious Text Burns NATO Statutes Instead
description: The protest came as Turkey agreed to clear the way for Sweden to join the alliance and after the burning of a Quran in Stockholm.
content: A man burned pages of NATO’s bylaws on Wednesday to protest Sweden’s bid to join the alliance, changing gears after planning to burn a religious text.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Mountain Valley Pipeline Halted as Legal Wrangling Heats Up
description: A federal court in Richmond has held up construction, despite a law passed by Congress last month that says it no longer has jurisdiction over the pipeline.
content: A federal court in Richmond has halted construction of the Mountain Valley Pipeline, setting off a battle with Congress that could end up at the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Maggie Siff and Erica Schmidt on a Williams Play ‘Shot Through With Desire’
description: “Orpheus Descending,” a rarely revived play about the treatment of outsiders, has only become more meaningful for its star and its director.
content: After Maggie Siff’s husband died of brain cancer in 2021, the last thing she wanted to do was a play about a woman with a husband dying of cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Wall Street’s Recession Warning Is Flashing. Some Wonder if It’s Wrong.
description: The yield curve has been suggesting since last year that the economy was headed for a slump.
content: Some investors believe that a recession warning that has been flashing on Wall Street for the past year may be sending a false signal — and think instead that the Federal Reserve will be able to tame inflation and still escape a deep downturn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Why a Tiny Trough Garden Always Attracts an Audience
description: They may not be the showiest thing on the patio, but these miniature landscapes inevitably take center stage: “It’s about being in Lilliputian land.”
content: If you can make space for a miniature rock garden — one of tiny plants growing within the confines of a faux-stone trough — the promise of an outsize payoff awaits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: It is Jeremy Allen White vs. Jason Sudeikis in the comedy actors race.
description: White, the star of “The Bear,” will seek to break Sudeikis’s “Ted Lasso” winning streak.
content: On the one hand, Jason Sudeikis is on a roll. He’s won the best actor in a comedy award two consecutive years for playing the title role in “Ted Lasso.” But can one ambitious and anxious chef topple him?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Developments on Ukraine’s bid to join NATO.
content: NATO leaders meeting at a summit in Vilnius, Lithuania, agreed in a joint statement to offer Ukraine an invitation to join the military alliance. But they remained vague on how and when, wording that essentially marked a victory for President Biden, who has said that Ukraine was not ready to be a member. European states closest to Russia have pushed for faster support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best Prime Day Deals Under $100
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Hunger’ and More
description: I’m a reporter-researcher in The Times’s Seoul bureau. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
content: I’m a reporter-researcher in The Times’s Seoul bureau. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
source.name: The New York Times

title: These National Parks Are Welcoming Stargazers This Summer and Fall
source.name: The New York Times

title: GWS-NATO-EXPLAINER
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and The Associated Press
title: Record-Breaking Storm Swamps Towns in Vermont
description: A two-day storm dumped more than eight inches of rain on some parts of the state.
content: A two-day storm dumped more than eight inches of rain on some parts of the state.
source.name: The New York Times
